entry.title: How to Use SAP Extensibility Wizard in SAP S/4HANA Clean Core
entry.content:
A Comprehensive Guide to Extending SAP S/4HANA with the SAP Extensibility Wizard â€” Without Compromising Your Clean Core

Introduction

Extensibility is a critical aspect of SAP S/4HANA, enabling organizations to tailor the system to their unique business needs while maintaining stability and upgrade readiness. In this guide, we will explore the SAP Extensibility Wizard, a powerful tool designed to help developers extend SAP S/4HANA in a clean and controlled way.

What Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard?

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a guided tool provided by SAP that simplifies the process of creating extensions. It ensures that developers can add custom functionality without modifying the core system, thereby preserving the clean core principle. This approach guarantees that upgrades remain smooth and that the system stays resilient over time.

Availability: Public Cloud vs. Private Cloud

A common question arises: Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard available only in the Public Cloud, or also in the Private Cloud?

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud â€“ Public Edition):
    The wizard is primarily available here. It supports clean-core extensibility and helps organizations build safe, upgradeâ€‘friendly extensions.
  • Private Cloud / Onâ€‘Premise:
    Extensibility is possible through other approaches such as inâ€‘app extensibility, ABAP Cloud, and sideâ€‘byâ€‘side extensions on SAP BTP. However, the wizard itself is not provided in the same way as in the Public Cloud.

In summary:

  • Public Cloud â†’ Wizard available.
  • Private Cloud / Onâ€‘Premise â†’ Extensibility options exist, but without the wizard.

Focus of This Blog

This blog will focus on the SAP Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud â€“ Public Edition.

How to Use the Extensibility Wizard

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition extensibility wizard, developers can:

  • Create onâ€‘stack extensions such as custom fields and custom logic.
  • Build sideâ€‘byâ€‘side extensions like custom processes using SAP Build Process Automation.

This guided approach ensures that extensions are implemented efficiently, securely, and in alignment with SAPâ€™s cleanâ€‘core strategy.

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a key enabler for organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By leveraging this tool, businesses can extend their systems with confidence, ensuring that customizations remain upgradeâ€‘safe and futureâ€‘proof.

 

Detailed Steps:

Use Case : We will create a sales order approval process .

1. Navigate to SAP S4/HANA Fiori Launchpad.

1.1 Select Business Application Manage Sales Orders. 

1.2  Navigate to Create Extension

 

1.3 In this case , we will select custom process.

The process can start based on various triggers 

1.4 Select Business Event from SAP S4/HANA, that Triggers the process

1.5 Select Event Object

1.6 Select the SalesOrder create event.

1.7 Click Preview to see all the options you selected on previous screens, and make any necessary corrections.

1.8 Click Create , to create the process in SAP Build.

1.9 The extension is now available and can also be opened in SAP Build.

1.10 When you select Open Extension, the system launches another tab that opens the process.

1.11 The Process Automation project overview page is now displayed. Select SalesOrder Approval.

1.12 Extension is now openEd in SAP Build , Start design of the process.

The Business context is carried over from SAP S4/HANA to SAP Build .

1.13 You can add an action, form , or approval . To get further details on the sales order, you need to call an action .

1.14 In this use case , we will call sales order read API , to fetch the sales order details.

1.15 Browse the library to search for  the relevant APIs .

1.16 Select read sales order API to get details of the sales order, The business context and system ID were automatically pulled in from SAP S4/HANA .

1.17 The action to read the sales order has now been added . Now users can design the process according to their needs. The user now wants to initiate a workflow that sends an email to the approver for sales order approval .

1.18 The email will include the sales order details , allowing approver to review and approve it . we're utilizing AI to generate the process , Enter the prompt to add an approval step and send the sales order details to the approver via email.

1.19 AI has now added the process step to read the sales order and email, The sales order details to the approver .

 

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard empowers organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to extend their systems safely and efficiently, without compromising the clean core. By leveraging guided tools for custom fields, logic, and sideâ€‘byâ€‘side processes, businesses can innovate while staying upgradeâ€‘ready.

Extensibility in SAP is not just about adding featuresâ€”itâ€™s about doing so in a way that keeps your system futureâ€‘proof. With the wizard, you can confidently build the extensions your business needs today, while ensuring smooth upgrades tomorrow.

entry.title: SAPUI5 Table Selection: SingleToggle vs Custom Single-Selection with Checkboxes
entry.content:
Introduction:

While building a table in SAPUI5, I faced the challenge of allowing users to select only one row at a time, while also ensuring a clean and intuitive interface. This led me to explore two approaches for implementing single-row selection using SingleToggle and a custom single-selection with checkboxes approach.

The goal was simple: Allow users to select only one row at a time. However, I also needed to give them a checkbox interface, which led me to try two solutions.

 

Option 1: Using SingleToggle

SAPUI5 offers a built-in SingleToggle selection mode that works well when you don't need checkboxes and only need to highlight one row at a time.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="SingleToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
How it's works?

  • Only one row can be selected.

  • Clicking the same row again deselects it.

  • No checkboxes; just row highlighting.

 SingleToggle is perfect for simple selection without checkboxes.

 

Option 2: Custom Single Selection with Checkboxes

When users expect checkboxes, but you still want to limit selection to one row, you can use MultiToggle mode combined with a custom event handler.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="MultiToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
Controller Logic:
onAppointmentRowSelectionChange: function (oEvent) {
    this.oAppointmentTable = oEvent.getSource();
    const aSelectedIndices = this.oAppointmentTable.getSelectedIndices();

    if (aSelectedIndices.length > 1) {
        const iLastIndex = oEvent.getParameter("rowIndex");
        this.oAppointmentTable.clearSelection();
        this.oAppointmentTable.addSelectionInterval(iLastIndex, iLastIndex);
    }
}
How it's works?

  • Only one checkbox is selected at a time

  • Shows checkboxes for selection

  • Provides intuitive user experience

This custom solution allows for single selection with checkboxes, giving users a familiar UI while ensuring only one row is selected.

 

Choosing the Right Approach

Use CaseRecommended Option

Simple highlight-only single selectionSingleToggle
Need checkboxes but still restrict to a single selectionCustom handler (as shown above)

 

Concluding Thoughts!

SAPUI5 gives us flexibility for row selection. If we just need single selection without checkboxes, SingleToggle is the way to go. However, if checkboxes are required, the custom handler approach ensures users can only select one row at a time while maintaining a clean UX.

Both solutions are simple to implement and offer clear user interactions. This is how I approached the issue, but if you have any other suggestions or methods for handling this, please feel free to share them here. I would love to learn from your experience too!

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Dear experts, Iâ€™m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: KPI Tags in SAP Fiori Elements List Report (OData V4) â€” Beyond Analytical Applications
entry.content:
Introduction

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) tags are commonly associated with analytical applications in SAP Fiori, but did you know you can also implement them in standard non-analytical list report pages?

OData V4 in SAP Fiori elements provides a manifest-based configuration approach that lets you add dynamic, clickable KPI indicators to any list report pageâ€”without needing an analytical service.

This blog walks you through the official implementation approach to show how to:

  • Configure KPI tags in manifest.json
  • Create reusable KPI fragments with the macros:KPITag building block
  • Bind dynamic data and handle press events
  • Understand the architecture and design patterns

Why KPI Tags Matter in List Reports

A KPI tag is a compact, clickable indicator that displays:

  • A numerical value (e.g., total cost, contribution amount, order count)
  • A unit or measurement (currency, percentage, days)
  • A visual status (color-coded: Success, Warning, Error, Information)
  • Optional icon and tooltip

In list reports, KPI tags provide at-a-glance insights without cluttering the data table. They're especially valuable for:

  • HR & Benefits applications â€” Show headcount, enrollment rates, total costs
  • Sales dashboards â€” Display order counts, revenue, pipeline value
  • Finance reports â€” Highlight outstanding invoices, approvals pending
  • Operations â€” Monitor KPIs like availability, efficiency, cycle time

Part 1: Understanding the Two Approaches

Approach 1: Analytical Applications (Analytical List Pages)

  • Requires an analytical data source with aggregated/pre-calculated data
  • Configured via CDS annotations in the backend as well as manifest configuration in UI
  • Example: SAP Analytical List Pages (ALP)
  • Best for: Large-scale data analysis, multi-dimensional analytics, pre-aggregated metrics

Approach 2: OData V4 List Reports (What This Blog Covers)

  • Uses manifest-based configuration + custom XML fragments
  • Works with any non-analytical OData V4 service
  • Configuration entirely in the frontend (manifest.json + UI5 fragments)
  • Fully customizable via UI5 controller extensions
  • Best for: Standard enterprise list reports, responsive dashboards, interactive KPIs

This approach is ideal for developers who want simplicity and flexibility without backend annotation complexity.

Part 2: Setting Up KPI Tags in manifest.json

KPI tags are registered in the manifest under the keyPerformanceIndicators section within the list report target:

"targets": {
  "mainPage": {
    "type": "Component",
    "id": "Default",
    "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
    "options": {
      "settings": {
        "contextPath": "/RootEntity",
        "variantManagement": "None",
        "initialLoad": true,
        "keyPerformanceIndicators": {
          "myKPITag": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITag"
          },
          "myKPIWithPress": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITagWithPress"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Key Points:

  • keyPerformanceIndicators â€” Container for all KPI definitions in this page

  • myKPITag, myKPIWithPress â€” Unique identifiers for each KPI block (you can name these anything)

  • template â€” Path to the fragment file (can be in your app namespace or SAP's example path)

You can define multiple KPI blocks by adding more entries. Each entry corresponds to one fragment template.

Part 3: Building KPI Fragments with the macros:KPITag Building Block

SAP recommends using the KPI building block (macros:KPITag) to maintain consistent design with analytical applications.

Simple KPI Fragment (Static Values)

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  
  <macros:KPITag
    number="0"
    unit="Days"
    status="Error"
    showIcon="true"
    press=".extension.sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.LRExtend.onKPIPressed"
  />
  
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Properties Reference

Property

Type

Purpose

Example

number

Number

The KPI value to display

0, 5000, 15.5

unit

String

Unit or measurement label

"Days", "USD", "%"

status

String

Visual indicator color

"Success", "Warning", "Error", "Information"

showIcon

Boolean

Display status icon

true / false

press

String

Event handler for click

.extension.[controller.path].onKPIPressed

tooltip

String

Hover text

"Total Orders"

visible

Boolean

Conditional visibility

true / false

enabled

Boolean

Enable/disable interaction

true / false

Part 4: Handling KPI Press Events

When a KPI tag is clicked, the press handler in your controller extension is triggered:

Step 1: Define the Controller Extension

In your manifest, register a controller extension for the ListReport:

"sap.ui5": {
  "extends": {
    "extensions": {
      "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
        "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
          "controllerName": "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 2: Implement the Press Handler

In your ListReportExt.controller.js:

sap.ui.define(
  ["sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension"],
  function(ControllerExtension) {
    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
      {
        onKPIPressed: function(oEvent) {
          const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
          const sKPIId = oSource.getId();
          
          sap.m.MessageToast.show("KPI " + sKPIId + " was pressed!");
          
          // Add custom logic here:
          // - Filter the table
          // - Navigate to detail page
          // - Show breakdown analysis
          // - Trigger backend action
        }
      }
    );
  }
);

Step 3: Register in Fragment

Reference the handler in your fragment's press event:

<macros:KPITag
  number="0"
  unit="Days"
  status="Error"
  press=".extension.your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onKPIPressed"
/>

Part 5: Building Multi-KPI Layouts with FlexBox

For a professional dashboard with multiple KPIs, use FlexBox for responsive layout:

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  <FlexBox 
    direction="Row"
    wrap="Wrap"
    gap="2rem"
    justifyContent="SpaceAround"
    alignItems="Start">
    
    <!-- KPI 1 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Total Orders" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="1234"
        unit="Orders"
        status="Success"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 2 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Revenue" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="523000"
        unit="USD"
        status="Information"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 3 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Pending Approvals" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="47"
        unit="Items"
        status="Warning"
      />
    </VBox>
  </FlexBox>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Part 6: Binding Data Models

To make KPIs dynamic (not just static values), you need to bind them to data models.

Creating a KPI Data Model

In your ListReportExt controller:

onInit: function() {
  const oKPIModel = new sap.ui.model.json.JSONModel({
    totalOrders: 1234,
    revenue: 523000,
    pendingApprovals: 47,
    costStatus: "Success"
  });
  
  this.getView().setModel(oKPIModel, "kpiModel");
}

Binding in Fragment

<macros:KPITag
  number="{kpiModel>/totalOrders}"
  unit="Orders"
  status="{kpiModel>/costStatus}"
/>

Updating Data Dynamically

fetchKPIData: function() {
  const oModel = this.getView().getModel(); // OData model
  
  oModel.read("/RootEntity", {
    success: (oData) => {
      const oKPIModel = this.getView().getModel("kpiModel");
      oKPIModel.setData({
        totalOrders: oData.OrderCount,
        revenue: oData.TotalRevenue,
        pendingApprovals: oData.ApprovalCount
      });
    }
  });
}

Part 7: Best Practices and Design Patterns

1. Responsive Design

  • Use wrap="Wrap" in FlexBox for mobile compatibility
  • Test on different screen sizes
  • Consider hiding KPIs on very small screens if needed

2. Status Color Coding

Use status colors to convey meaning:

  • Success (Green) â€” All good, target met
  • Warning (Orange) â€” Attention needed, approaching limit
  • Error (Red) â€” Critical, action required
  • Information (Blue) â€” Neutral, FYI

3. Meaningful Units

  • Always include a unit if applicable (currency, count, percentage, time)

4. Interactive Press Handlers

Make KPIs actionable:

  • Filter the list to show related records

  • Open a breakdown popover with summary data

5. Loading States

Use busy indicators while fetching data:

<FlexBox busy="{kpiModel>/loading}">
  <macros:KPITag number="{kpiModel>/value}" />
</FlexBox>

Part 8: Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue

Solution

KPI tags not showing

Verify manifest template path is correct; ensure fragment file exists at that location

Static values work, but binding doesn't

Check model name matches in binding (e.g., {kpiModel>/...}); verify model is set before fragment renders

Press event not firing

Ensure press handler includes .extension. prefix; verify controller extension is registered in manifest

Mobile layout broken

Add wrap="Wrap" to FlexBox; test responsive breakpoints; use sap.ui.Device for responsive logic

Blank KPI in production

Check backend OData service returns required fields; add error handling for failed reads

Part 9: Comparison â€” Analytical List Pages vs. OData V4 Manifest-Based KPIs

Configuration

CDS annotations + Manifest Configuration

Manifest Configuration only

Data Source

Analytical data models with aggregation

Any OData V4 service

Setup Complexity

High (requires analytical CDS views)

Low (JSON config + fragment)

Customization

Framework-driven

Full UI5 flexibility

Performance

Optimized for large aggregations

Good for summary metrics

Event Handling

Predefined navigation & analytics

Custom controller logic

Best For

Enterprise analytics dashboards

Standard business apps with KPI summaries

Learning Curve

Steep (analytics concepts)

Gentle (standard UI5 patterns)

Part 10: Live Example Reference

SAP provides a working example in the Flexible Programming Model Explorer:

Custom KPI Tags in List Report â€” FPM Explorer

This interactive demo shows:

  • Static KPI tags

  • KPI tags with press events

  • Various status types and layouts
  • Responsive behavior

Recommended: Clone this example and adapt it to your use case.

Part 11: What's Next? â€” Custom Charts & KPI Visualization

Coming in Next Blog:

In this blog, we learned how to add interactive KPI tags to any list report page. But what happens when users click on a KPI?

In the next blog, we'll explore:

  1. Building Custom Charts â€” Visualize KPI data using chart libraries
  2. Mapping KPI Data to Chart Models â€” Prepare and transform data from your OData service
  3. Opening Charts in Dialogs/Popovers â€” Display detailed analysis when KPI is clicked
  4. Multi-dimensional Visualizations â€” Show data breakdowns by different dimensions
  5. Dynamic Chart Updates â€” Refresh visualizations based on filter selections

Imagine clicking on a "Revenue" KPI and instantly seeing a pie chart breakdown by product category, or a bar chart comparing revenue across regions. That's what we'll build next!

Resources

  • SAP Fiori Elements Documentation â€” Creating Key Performance Indicators
  • macros:KPITag API Reference
  • FPM Explorer â€” Custom KPI Tags Example
  • SAP Community â€” Fiori Elements
  • Analytical List Page Documentation

Summary

KPI tags are not limited to analytical applications. By leveraging OData V4's manifest-based configuration and SAP UI5's flexible architecture, you can add powerful, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page.

Key Takeaways:

  • KPI tags work with standard (non-analytical) OData V4 services

  • Configuration is simple: manifest entry + fragment + optional controller logic

  • Full customization via UI5 â€” binding, styling, event handling

  • Responsive design built-in via FlexBox

  • Press handlers enable analysis and interaction

Whether you're building HR dashboards, sales pipelines, financial reports, or operational monitors, KPI tags can elevate user experience by providing instant insights at a glance.

Start experimenting with the FPM Explorer example today, and stay tuned for our next blog on custom charts and KPI visualization!

Questions or feedback? Drop a comment belowâ€”I'd love to hear about your KPI use cases!

entry.title: Customize SAP Build Workzone Side Menu Icons by use of a Shell Plugin
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Build Work Zone serves as a central entry point for business users with personalized, role-based access to SAP and third-party applications. With customers wanting to customize its look and feel, adding custom buttons and custom visual representation of navigation items, this blog posts aims at showing how to achieve this customization by the use of Shell Plugins. 

1. What you will learn in this blogpost

You will learn how to spin up a workzone subscription, and customize the workzone shell by use of a shell plugin. This will help you to customize the layout, add action buttons and also change icons on the side menu of the workzone.

2. What Shell Plugins do

With the standard configuration, the outer shell of the workzone is limited and customers want to extend the functionality, adding buttons to the shell or even changing its look and feel. This can be achieved by the use of a Shell Plugin.

3. First steps

To follow this blog post you need to complete the following prerequisites:

  • Have a SAP BTP subaccount or a SAP BTP Trial Account
  • Have a SAP Build Workzone Standard Edition Subscription (this is important as the advanced edition does not yet allow to display the menu on the side)
  • Configure your site with the following attributes (important is to set the menu option to "side" - this option only appears if the view mode is set to "Spaces and Pages"

  • Have a SAP Business Application Studio subscription or VSCode installed with the CF CLI, MBT tools
  • Know how to create subscriptions
  • Know to assign role collections to your user
  • Have a Space, a Page and an App set up in the workzone and assigned to the role "Everyone"

4. Shortcut with Terraform and Github

I have created a GitHub repo (https://github.com/cnbscorp/btp-workzone-shell-plugin.git) which helps you to spin up the resources in your trial account and deploy the Shell Plugin via CF CLI. If you are familiar with terraform or even have an own terraform repo managing you BTP, this can save you some click-ops activity in the BTP Cockpit. I will provide a detailed walk-through on how to use terraform in BTP in a separate post, the main focus of this blog post is to customize the workzone shell.

5. Setup on SAP BTP

  • All the instructions on how to deploy this module is stated in the README file on GitHub, please be careful with deploying via terraform if you are not familiar with it.
  • For developers deploying to an already configured subaccount, be careful not to override existing configuration.

6. Setup on SAP BAS / VSCode

1. Make use of the Fiori Application Wizard (BAS has this extension already installed)

  • Create Project from Temlate: Basic
  • Data Source: None
  • View Name: ShellPlugin
  • Target: Cloud Foundry

2. Navigate to the manifest.json file in the webapp/ folder

  • Enrich the file with the with the following configuration
    "crossNavigation": {
      "inbounds": {
        "Shell-plugin": {
          "semanticObject": "Shell",
          "action": "plugin",
          "title": "{{Shell-plugin.flpTitle}}",
          "hideLauncher": true,
          "icon": "sap-icon://pushpin-on",
          "signature": {
            "parameters": {},
            "additionalParameters": "allowed"
          }
        }
      }
    }

and

  "sap.flp": {
    "type": "plugin"
  }

3. Customize the component.js file in thewebapp/ folder. 

init() {
            UIComponent.prototype.init.apply(this, arguments);
            this.setModel(models.createDeviceModel(), "device");
            this.getRouter().initialize();

            this._getRenderer().then((oRenderer) => {
                oRenderer.addHeaderEndItem({
                    icon: "sap-icon://add",
                    tooltip: "Add bookmark",
                    press: () => {
                        const oDialog = new Dialog({
                            title: "What's new",
                            content: new Text({ text: "Hello from shell plugin!" }),
                            beginButton: new Button({
                                text: "OK",
                                press: () => oDialog.close()
                            }),
                            afterClose: () => oDialog.destroy()
                        });
                        oDialog.open();
                    }
                }, true, false);
                this._updateNavIcons();
            });
        },

        _getRenderer() {
            var oRenderer = sap.ushell.Container.getRenderer("fiori2");
            return (oRenderer && typeof oRenderer.then === "function") ? oRenderer : Promise.resolve(oRenderer);
        },

        _getNavList() {
            try {
                const oNavList = sap.ui.getCore().byId("__list0"); // your NavigationList ID
                if (!oNavList) {
                    console.warn("NavigationList control not found");
                    return null;
                }
                return oNavList.getItems ? oNavList.getItems() : [];
            } catch (err) {
                console.error("Error retrieving NavigationList items", err);
                return null;
            }
        },

        _updateNavIcons() {
            const aItems = this._getNavList();
            if (!aItems) return;

            const _updateItem = (oItem) => {

                const sText = oItem.getText();
                switch (sText) {
                    case "Cool Space":
                        oItem.setIcon("sap-icon://customer-and-contacts"); break;
                    default:
                        oItem.setIcon("sap-icon://document"); break;
                }

                console.log(`Updated icon for "${sText}" to "${oItem.getIcon()}"`);

                if (oItem.getItems && oItem.getItems().length > 0) {
                    oItem.getItems().forEach(_updateItem);
                }
            };

            aItems.forEach(_updateItem);
        }
  • Also add the following to your sap.ui.define function:
sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/UIComponent",
    "mrt/shellplugin/model/models",
    "sap/m/Dialog",
    "sap/m/Button",
    "sap/m/Text"
], (UIComponent, models, Dialog, Button, Text) =>

7. Deploy the Shell Plugin

  • Right click on the mta.yaml file
  • Click on Build MTA Project

entry.title: Using Cline with SAP AI Core in VS Code: A Complete Setup Guide
entry.content:
As SAP developers, we spend our days juggling multiple tools such as code editors, documentation pages, AI Launchpad, and API testing platforms. With information scattered across different places, a significant amount of time is lost switching between tabs instead of focusing on actual development. Now imagine if SAPâ€™s GenAI capabilities were available right where you work, ready to support you the moment you need them.

That is exactly what Cline integrated with SAP AI Core delivers. Cline works like an AI coding partner inside your development environment, and when connected to SAP AI Core, it brings SAPâ€™s GenAI Hub models directly into your workflow. There are no API calls to write and no dashboards to open. You simply type a prompt and receive instant, SAP-aware assistance for CAP, UI5, CDS, integrations, and more.

Setting it up is simple. Install two extensions and connect your SAP AI Core service key. In just a few minutes, your development environment transforms into an AI-enhanced workspace where you can generate code, debug faster, understand complex logic, and boost productivity without breaking your flow.

This blog walks you through that setup and helps you experience how seamless and powerful SAP development becomes when GenAI is built directly into your everyday tools.

entry.title: SAP S4HANA Fiori Launchpad authentication via IAS (SAP Cloud Identity services)
entry.content:
Hello,

This blog will help us configure our S4HANA Fiori through SAP Cloud Identity Services and still using our own corporate IDP.

This is one of prerequisite of enabling joule for S4HANA Fiori launchpad for private cloud edition.

Our organization is already having SAML authentication for our Fiori users with our corporate IDP but in order to use Joule within Fiori SAP Fiori should also use same authentication method as that of Joule.

 Architectural flow 

Steps to integrate Fiori with IAS

  1. Get the SAML Metadata of Your Identity Authentication Tenant
  2. Create an App for Your SAP S/4HANA Solution
  3. Enable the ABAP Platform as an SAML Service Provider
  4. Trust Identity Authentication as an Identity Provider
  5. Trust the ABAP Platform Client as a Service Provider
  6. Configure Corporate IDP in SAP IAS
  7. Configuring the Conditional authentication for your app in IAS

Get the SAML Metadata of Your Identity Authentication Tenant

Login to your IAS tenant --> https://<tenant ID>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Tenant Settings tile.

 

Choose the SAML 2.0 Configuration list item.

Choose Download Metadata File.

From the Signing Certificate section, download the certificate too.

 

Create an App for Your SAP S/4HANA Solution

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Applications tile.

Choose the Create button.

Enter the required information.

 

Set the Application Type to SAP on-premise Solution.

Click on create.

 

Enable the ABAP Platform as an SAML Service Provider

Login to your S4HANA system and open SAML 2.0 Configuration (transaction SAML2).

If your ABAP client has never been configured for SAML, you see the message Client "<Client_Id>" is not configured to support SAML 2.0.

To enable the configuration, choose Enable SAML 2.0 Support -->  Create SAML 2.0 Local Provider.

 
 
Enter a name for the provider.
 

 

 

 
Choose Metadata.

Save the metadata to a file, such as abap_client_metadata.xml.

Trust Identity Authentication as an Identity Provider

In SAML2 tcode goto Trusted Provider and click on add

Select the metadata file you downloaded from your Identity Authentication tenant for upload and choose Next.

Then you need to choose the certificate which you have downloaded from tenant setting

once you finish the wizard. provider is added as shown below

click on identity federation and click add

you can save and activate this provider

 

Trust the ABAP Platform Client as a Service Provider

login to SAP IAS https://<tenant ID>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Applications tile.

Select the application you created for your ABAP Platform client

Under the Trust tab, choose SAML 2.0 Configuration.

 

Upload the service provider metadata XML file which you downloaded from SAML2 tcode

 

Configure Corporate IDP in SAP IAS

prerequisite : you need metadata file from your corporate IDP 

Login to IAS and go to Identity provided --> Corporate Identity Providers

click on SAML configuration

 

 

Name ID format you can keep unspecified

Configuring the Conditional authentication for your app in IAS

login to IAS and click on application and resource 

select your application " SAP ABAP " in my case

then scroll down to conditional authentication

choose the corporate IDP which you create in above step and click on save

you have to trust your corporate IDP 

you are all set

now when request comes from SAP Fiori it will be redirected to SAP IAS and SAP IAS will redirect that request to your corporate IDP. It will pass the authentication and same will be pass on to your SAP application by SAP IAS. It will just act like proxy.

In case if you are not using Corporate IDP for login then you need to create each SAP user in your SAP IAS so that they can login fiori with your SAP IAS login credentails.

 

Reference Article : https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/identity-authentication-configuration-for-sap-s-4hana?locale=en-US

entry.title: SAP UI5 - QUnit-Testing
entry.content:
• 1. Setup
  • 1.1 Installing the required libraries
  • 1.2 Folder structure
  • 1.2.1 AllTests.js
  • 1.2.2 unitTests.qunit.html
  • 1.2.3 unitTests.qunit.js
  • 2. Implementing unit tests
  • 2.1 Basic structure of a test module
  • 2.2 Simple Test using sinon.stub and sinon.spy
  • 2.3 Testing functions with Return Values or Promises
  • 2.4 Testing error cases and exceptions
  • 2.5 Larger example with more branches
  • 3. Running tests and coverage
  • 3.1 Running tests
  • 3.2 Test results in the QUnit interface
  • 3.3 Enabling code coverage
  • 3.4 Detailed view of individual files
  • 3.5 Coverage reports
  • 4. Conclusion

In this post, I share practical experience with QUnit tests from my UI5 projects.
This post is aimed at developers who are already familiar with SAP UI5 and just getting started with QUnit. It was originally intended as an onboarding guide, but I noticed that information on this topic is quite scattered.
The examples in this post are kept close to real project code and can also be used as a reference when implementing similar test cases.

 

1. Setup

1.1 Installing the required libraries

To implement and execute QUnit tests in a UI5 application, just a few libraries are needed.
We just add them to the dependencies section of the application's package.json.

Depending on the project, either a specific version or simply latest can be used.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For later test coverage analysis (see section 3. Running Tests & Coverage), an additional library should be included:

 

 

 

 

 

 

This library also needs to be added to the ui5.yaml under "server>customMiddleware>".

 

 

After adding the required libraries, they can be installed using:

npm install

 

1.2 Folder structure

The folder structure for the unit tests is quite simple and is set up as follows:

- webapp
   - test
      - unit
         AllTests.js
         unitTests.qunit.html
         unitTests.qunit.js

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The actual test files should ideally follow a structure similar to the application itself.
This not a rule -> just for readability
For example, if unit tests are required for BaseController.js, a corresponding folder controller and a file BaseController.js should be created inside the test directory:

- webapp
   - controller
      BaseController.js

   - test
      - unit
         - controller
            BaseController.js

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

1.2.1 AllTests.js

All QUnit tests to be executed are included in the define section of this file.
It is a central place where we can enable or disable tests for execution.

sap.ui.define([
    "./controller/BaseController",
    // "./controller/OtherController",
    // "./controller/OtherController2",
    // "./services/SampleService",
    // "./util/SampleFormatter",
], function () {
    "use strict";
});

(Tip)

When working on unit tests for a specific controller an running them frequently, tests for other controllers can be commented out here, so they are not executed each time.

 

1.2.2 unitTests.qunit.html

Short and simple: we start our tests using this file.
All required libraries for test execution are included here.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Unit tests for Template</title>
    <meta charset="utf-8">

    <script id="sap-ui-bootstrap"
        src="../../../../resources/sap-ui-core.js"
        data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{
            "app.unittester": "../"
        }'
        data-sap-ui-async="true"
        data-sap-ui-preload="async">
    </script>

    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.css">

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-junit.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-coverage-istanbul.js"
        data-sap-ui-cover-only="app/unittester/"
        data-sap-ui-cover-never="app/unittester/test, app/unittester/localServices, app/unittester/services">
    </script>

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

    <script src="unitTests.qunit.js"></script>
</head>

<body>
    <div id="qunit"></div>
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div>
</body>
</html>

Just a few notes on the most important scripts that are included here (because we will use them later).

QUnit

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.css">
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.js"></script>
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-junit.js"></script>

(Roughly summarized) The actual QUnit framework is included here.

sinon and sinon-qunit

<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

These libraries enable spying, stubbing and mocking dependencies.

qunit-coverage-istanbul.js (Code Coverage Integration)

<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-coverage-istanbul.js"
        data-sap-ui-cover-only="app/unittester/"
        data-sap-ui-cover-never="[
           app/unittester/test, 
           app/unittester/localServices, 
           app/unittester/services
        ]">
</script>

This is required later for code coverage.

(Note) In this post, we use Istanbul for code coverage.
Of course, other options such as Karma can also be used if desired.

Important attributes:

  • data-sap-ui-cover-only
    files to be included in the coverage
  • data-sap-ui-cover-never
    files and directories to be excluded from coverage

 

1.2.3 unitTests.qunit.js

This is the central entry point for the unit tests.
Here we only include the tests from AllTests.js in the define section and start the test run.

QUnit.config.autostart = false;

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () {
    "use strict";

    sap.ui.require([
        "app/unittester/test/unit/AllTests"
    ], function () {
        QUnit.start();
    });
});

2. Implementing unit tests

In this example, we will look at some unit tests for the BaseController as well as the basic structure.
In addition, we will see how sinon can be used to handle dependencies.

2.1 Basic structure of a test module

Each module has its own tests and provides lifecycle hooks such as beforeEach and afterEach.
The modules can be structured freely, depending on the requirements.

We start with a test module for BaseController.js and implement the module in the test file.
(webapp>test>unit>controller>BaseController)

sap.ui.define([
	"app/unittester/controller/BaseController",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit",
], function(BaseController) {
	"use strict";
	
	/**
	* Module
	*/
	QUnit.module("Module", {
	   beforeEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController = new BaseController();
	   },
	   afterEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController.destroy();
	   }
	});
	
});

First, we include the actual BaseController and the two sinon libraries in the define statement.

After that, the module itself:
The lifecycle functions of the module are executed before and after each test.
In order to test the functions of the BaseController, we instatiate it before the test and destroy it afterwards.

2.2 Simple Test using sinon.stub and sinon.spy

In our first test, we will take the getRouter function from our BaseController.

getRouter: function() {
	return this.getOwnerComponent().getRouter();
},

We only want to test whether the function can be executed.

However, it has two dependencies:
this.getOwnerComponent and its function getRouter.

In order to test getRouter without having to instantiate all dependencies, we will "simulate" them with sinon.

This would look like the following:

sap.ui.define([
	"app/unittester/controller/BaseController",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit",
], function(BaseController) {
	"use strict";
	
	/**
	* Module
	*/
	QUnit.module("Module", {
	   beforeEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController = new BaseController();
	   },
	   afterEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController.destroy();
	   }
	});
	
	/**
	* BaseController - Check getRouter
	*/
	QUnit.test("BaseController - Check getRouter", function(assert) {
	   sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getOwnerComponent").returns({
		  getRouter: sinon.stub()
	   });

	   const fnSpy = sinon.spy(this.oBaseController, "getRouter");
	   this.oBaseController.getRouter();
	   assert.ok(fnSpy.calledOnce, "Check getRouter successful");
	});
	
});

The function flow:

In line 24, we create a stub for this.oBaseController (our controller instance) and listen for calls to the getOwnerComponent function.
As soon as this function is executed, a return value is "simulated" that provides another simulated function, getRouter.

After that, we create a spy for this.oBaseController, that listens for calls to the getRouter function.

Then comes the actual function call in line 29.

Finally, we use an assertion where we check (via fnSpy.calledOnce) whether getRouter was executed at least once within the function.

And that's basically it. Every following test has the same structure (sometimes more or less complex).

Running the test:
If we look at the coverage here now (more on this later), we can see that the function was executed exactly once:

 

 

 

2.3 Testing functions with Return Values or Promises

Many controller methods are asynchronous and return a Promise.

These tests are implemented using async and await.
Using await ensures that the test waits properly for execution to finish.

Example: onStartEditMode

onStartEditMode: async function () {
	try {
		this._fireSetViewBusy(true);
		await this.oDraftManager.onEdit();
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);				
	} finally {
		this._fireSetViewBusy(false);				
	}						
},

The corresponding test:

QUnit.test("BaseController - Start edit mode", async function (assert) {
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "_fireSetViewBusy");
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "evaluateException");

	this.oBaseController.oDraftManager = {
		onEdit: sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true))
	};		

	const fnSpy = sinon.spy(this.oBaseController, "onStartEditMode");
	await this.oBaseController.onStartEditMode();
	assert.ok(fnSpy.calledOnce, "onStartEditMode executed successfully");
});

2.4 Testing error cases and exceptions

Error cases are just as important as successful scenarios.

In this example, we provoke an error by not stubbing any dependencies, so the function runs into the error path.
This verifies that the error handling logic is executed correctly.

Example function onFullScreenPressed:

onFullScreenPressed: function() {
	try {
		this._fireSetLayout("MidColumnFullScreen");
		this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("util").setProperty(`/ViewControl/Layout`, "MidColumnFullScreen");
		return true;
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);
		return false;
	}
},

The test:

QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onFullScreenPressed Exception", async function(assert) {
	assert.notOk(await this.oBaseController.onFullScreenPressed(), "Check onFullScreenPressed Exception successful");
});

2.5 Larger example with more branches

A slightly larger example is the onCancel function, which is a bit more complex. 

The function checks whether changes exist in the current draft.

Several paths (branches):
Changes exist: the user is shown a dialog, where they can decide whether to discard the draft
No changes: the draft is discarded
Error case: an error message is shown

onCancel:

onCancel: async function(oEvent) {
	try {
		const oData = this.getView().getBindingContext().getObject();

		//are there changes?
		if (oData.DraftEntityCreationDateTime.toString() !== oData.DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime.toString()) {
			const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
			this._openDiscardDraftDialog(oSource);
			return true;
		} else {
			//no changes, so discard the draft
			return Promise.resolve(await this.onDiscardDraft());
		}
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);
		return false;
	}
},

We will now test all paths to achieve full coverage.

1. onCancel with draft changes

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel (with draft changes)
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel - with draft changes", async function(assert) {
	this.oBaseController.onDiscardDraft = sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true));
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "_openDiscardDraftDialog");
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getView").returns({
		getBindingContext: sinon.stub().returns({
			getObject: sinon.stub().returns({
				DraftEntityCreationDateTime: 1,
				DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime: 2
			})
		})
	});
	const oMockButton = new Button();
	const oEvent = {
		getSource: function() {
			return oMockButton;
		}
	};

	assert.ok(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(oEvent), "Check onCancel (with draft changes) successful");
});

2. onCancel without changes

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel (no draft changes)
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel - no changes", async function(assert) {
	this.oBaseController.onDiscardDraft = sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true));
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getView").returns({
		getBindingContext: sinon.stub().returns({
			getObject: sinon.stub().returns({
				DraftEntityCreationDateTime: 1,
				DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime: 1
			})
		})
	});

	assert.ok(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(), "Check onCancel (no draft changes) successful");
});

3. onCancel error case

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel Exception
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel Exception", async function(assert) {
	assert.notOk(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(), "Check onCancel Exception successful");
});

When we now run the tests, we can see that we have covered all paths (branches):

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. Running tests and coverage

Unit tests can be executed in different ways.
In practice, running them via an npm script has proven to be the most convenient option.

3.1 Running tests

Unit tests can be started using a script defined in package.json:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The test run is then started using the following command:

npm run unit-tests

Once the tests are started, the browser opens and all tests (that are not commented out in AllTests.js) are executed automatically.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3.2 Test results in the QUnit interface

After the tests have been executed, an overview is displayed in the browser showing which tests were successful an which were not.
This is also indicated by colors and shown together with an error message.

Example:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Failed tests can also be inspected in the browser console.

 

3.3 Enabling code coverage

Code coverage can be enabled using the checkbox "Enable coverage" in the QUnit toolbar.

 

 


Once enabled, tests are re-run automatically and an interactive coverage overview is displayed below the test results.

 

 

 

In the coverage overview, we can see the tested controllers and the information about the coverage itself.

statements and lines
Shows which lines of code were executed during the tests.

 

 

 

 

 

functions
Indicates which functions were called at least once.

 

 

branches
Shows whether different execution paths (e.g. if/else, try/catch) were actually tested.

 

 

 

3.4 Detailed view of individual files

Clicking a file opens a detailed coverage view.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

green lines were executed
red lines were not covered

 

 

 

 

 

 

3.5 Coverage reports

In addition to the browser view, a coverage report is generated under:
tmp/coverage-reports/html/index.html

Alternatevly, it can also be found in the IDE's project folder:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The report is updated automatically, can be opened in the browser independently.

4. Conclusion

With QUnit, we mainly focus on isolated controller logic and function behavior. 
Therefore keeping functions cleanly encapsulated and dependencies low during development leads to much easier unit tests

A note on coverage:
I know that coverage percentages are often defined as targets.
I have also seen that the temptation to push these numbers can be quite high by starting to test trivial functions (e.g. getters or setters). This usually backfires sooner or later.
It makes much more sense to focus on testing critical logic, error cases and especially different paths and branches.

In this post, I would like to share some of my experience with draft handling in FreeStyle applications.
After we decided in one of our projects to implement draft handling and at the same time had to consider our new component-based architecture, we encapsulated SAPâ€™s DraftController (sap.ui.generic.app.transaction.DraftController) in a way that made sense for our use case.

I describe one possible encapsulation of the DraftController in a service class called "DraftManager", which (depending on the project) can be integrated and used across FreeStyle applications.
This approach worked very well for us, especially since official documentation was quite limited at that time.

Important: In our application we use an OData V2 service (with CDS views) that is already prepared accordingly for draft handling.

1.1 Initialization

The DraftManager is a service class used to encapsulate the DraftController.
The following basic structure has proven itself in our projects and can be used as is or adapted and extended as needed.

When initializing the DraftManager in the controller, we only pass the component instance and the viewâ€™s binding context.

(Example)

this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);

The binding context is stored internally within the class for further processing and can be accessed or modified if required using the helper functions getActiveContext and setActiveContext.

Basic structure:

sap.ui.define([
  "sap/ui/generic/app/transaction/DraftController"
], function (DraftController) {
  "use strict";

  const DraftManager = function (oComponent, oContext) {
    this.oModel = oComponent.getModel();
    this.oDraftController = new DraftController(this.oModel);
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
    this.oDraftContext = null;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.setActiveContext = function (oContext) {
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.getActiveContext = function () {
    return this.oActiveContext;
  };

  return DraftManager;
});

 

1.2 Draft Functions in the DraftManager

The DraftManager can be extended as needed, but in this post I would like to focus in particular on the main draft handling functions (Activate, Edit, and Discard).

Determine or Create a Draft

The DraftController itself is relatively easy to use.
However, there are operations, such as Edit, that always require multiple steps.
If a draft already exists, a new one cannot be created and an error will occur.

To avoid having to implement the same check in every controller, this logic is encapsulated.
This way, only a single function needs to be executed.

In this example code, we first check whether a draft exists for the active view context.
If so, it is returned and the controller can rebind the view accordingly.
If not, a new draft is created.

If needed, success and error messages can also be handled inside the function (for example, if they should be consistent across several applications). We use our own separate error handling in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.getOrCreateEditDraft = async function () {
  const oExistingDraft = await this.oDraftController.getDraftForActiveEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  if (oExistingDraft && !oExistingDraft.context.getObject().IsActiveEntity) {
    this.oDraftContext = oExistingDraft.context;
    return this.oDraftContext;
  }

  const oDraft = await this.oDraftController.createEditDraftEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  this.oDraftContext = oDraft.context;
  return this.oDraftContext;
};

Activate a Draft

Activating a draft is pretty straightforward in this case. Here as well: The function can be extended as needed (error + success handling e.g.)

DraftManager.prototype.activateDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.activateDraftEntity(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oActiveContext = this.oDraftContext;
};

Discard a Draft

Discarding a draft is also easy to implement in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.discardDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.discardDraft(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oDraftContext = null;
};

2. Instantiating the DraftManager in the Controller

As mentioned at the beginning, the DraftManager can be instantiated quite easily.

Example: We have a master/detail application with an onRouteMatched function in the detail controller.
Assume we have a SmartTable on the master page and navigate to the detail page after clicking on an entry.
Here, we pass the corresponding bound id (or guid) of the list item and the HasActiveEntity property.

Using this properties, we now create a raw context (helper function _loadContext) and start instantiating the DraftManager .

onRouteMatched: async function (oEvent) {
  const sId = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").UUID;
  const bActive = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").HasActiveEntity;

  try {
	const oContext = await this._loadContext("/EntitySet", { "UUID": sId, "IsActiveEntity": bActive });
	this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);
  } catch (oError) {
	//error handling
  }  
}
_loadContext: async function (sEntity, oContextParameters) {
	const oModel = this.getView().getModel();
	await oModel.metadataLoaded();
	const sKey = oModel.createKey(sEntity, oContextParameters);
	const oContext = new sap.ui.model.Context(oModel, sKey);
	return Promise.resolve(oContext);
},

After that, the DraftManager is instantiated and can be used.

3. Using the DraftManager in the Controller

From this point on things become much more relaxed, as encapsulating the draft logic significantly reduces the number of operations in the controller.

I will keep the following examples to a minimum. Depending on the requirements, these can of course become more complex.

For rebinding/refreshing the view, we're using the following helper function:

_bindView: async function (sId, bIsActiveEntity) {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    this.getView().bindElement({
      path: `/EntitySet(UUID=guid'${sId}',IsActiveEntity=${bIsActiveEntity})`,
      parameters: {
        expand: "DraftAdministrativeData"
      },
      events: {
        change: (oEvent) => {
          resolve(oEvent.getSource().getBoundContext());
        }
      }
    });
  });
};

3.1 Start Editing

Editing has now become a fire-and-forget function, as everything is nicely encapsulated.
After each draft operation, the view should be updated (in this case using _bindView).

onEdit: async function () {
	try {	
		const oDraftContext = await this.oDraftManager.getOrCreateEditDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			oDraftContext.getProperty("UUID"),
			oDraftContext.getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);		
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.2 Save

After activating the draft, the view is rebound to the active entity.

onSave: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.activateDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);	
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.3 Cancel

When canceling, the draft is discarded and the view is rebound to the active context.

onDiscard: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.discardDraft();
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

4. DraftHandling and MERGE lock errors

One important learning from our projects was dealing with MERGE lock errors.
As soon as draft handling is applied to larger views with many form fields and especially rich text editors, you will sooner or later run into locking issues, as we did.

This happens because the DraftController triggers a MERGE request on every change in the view (which is correct behavior).
However, if too many changes are performed too quickly, multiple MERGE requests can be sent at the same time and end up locking each other.

This can easily be reproduced with a rich text editor in the view by pressing the Enter key very quickly. The result is a large number of lock errors (The draft itself is still updated correctly, but this can become quite annoying when working with messaging).

Our solution for this was to work with deferredGroups and changeGroups.

In order to get this to work with the DraftController and the service class, we use the merge timer provided by SAP.

First we start by setting the deferredGroup and changeGroup in the onInit function of the view controller.

this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setDeferredGroups(["Changes"]);
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setChangeGroups({
  "*": {
    groupId: "Changes",
    changeSetId: "Changes",
    single: false
  }
});
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().attachPropertyChange(this.onEnqueueSubmitChanges.bind(this, 1));

After that we define the propertyChange handler function onEnqueueSubmitChanges.

onEnqueueSubmitChanges: function (nIntervalInSeconds) {
  const mParameters = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("util").getProperty("/ViewControl/batchParameters");
  this.oDraftManager.triggerSubmitChanges(nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters);
}

And finally, we define a new DraftManager function triggerSubmitChanges, which bundles the requests using the merge timer and submits them accordingly.

oDraftManager.prototype.triggerSubmitChanges = function (nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters) {
  const oDraftMergeTimer = this.oDraftController._oDraftMergeTimer;
  if (!oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID) {
    oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = setTimeout(() => {
      oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = null;
      if (this.oModel.hasPendingChanges()) {
        this.oDraftController.triggerSubmitChanges(mParameters)
          .catch((oError) => {
            console.error("Error during submit changes:", oError);
          });
      }
    }, (nIntervalInSeconds || 0) * 1000);
  }
};

5. Conclusion

I have reduced the examples to the basics, as they can be extended as needed. We had very good experience with this service class, and draft handling in FreeStyle applications in combination with an OData V2 service worked very well.

The DraftController can of course also be used directly in the controller.
However, as mentioned before, encapsulating it is worthwhile when working with a larger application architecture, especially when testing is relevant in the project.

entry.title: Navigate SAP Fiori launchpad with Ease: Launch Apps via Transaction Codes
entry.content:
Overview

We have introduced an innovative feature in the SAP Fiori launchpad offering a swift and efficient way to navigate to applications using transaction codes**.

Users can now perform quick search on transaction code with instant navigation to the corresponding application.

Seamless In-Place and Ex-Place Navigation

  • In-Place Launch: If you have access to a role-based app, simply enter /n followed by the transaction code to launch it in the same browser tab. 

  • Ex-Place Launch: For opening apps in a new browser tab, use /o followed by the transaction code. 

  • Navigation to Start Page: Easily return to the start page with /n, or open it in a new tab with /o.

Key Benefits

  • Instant App Access: Accelerate your workflow with immediate app navigation.
  • Enhanced User Experience: Business users enjoy an empowering and intuitive navigation experience.
  • Familiarity for SAP GUI Users: Mimics the classic navigation style for those accustomed to transaction codes in SAP GUI.

Initial Release Restrictions

Please note that some restrictions apply to this feature in its initial release. For detailed information, refer to SAP Note 3687260.

Feature Release Horizon

This feature is included in version 2602 across various platforms:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Official Documentation
  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment: Official Documentation (Coming Soon)
  • SAP Integrated Business Planning: Official Documentation (Coming Soon)
Experience the power of seamless navigation and user empowerment while keeping your workflows efficient and intuitive with this cutting-edge feature!

** Discovering Transaction Codes for applications

Some of the ways to identify the transaction code corresponding to an application include:

1. Access the  Fiori reference library , typically for SAP Fiori and SAP GUI applications the  App ID information would correspond to the transaction code.

2. Navigate to an application by other means such as clicking on the tile and invoke the About dialog via User menu to find the transaction code.

Feel free to share any additional shortcuts or cheat sheets you may have in the comments section!

entry.title: Step-By-Step Guide: Creating Your First RAP Application using OData V4 and Transporting to Quality
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, we will walk through the detailed steps to create your first RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) application and correctly move it to the Quality system. This blog also highlights mandatory steps before transport and common mistakes that beginners usually make, based on real project experience.

Target Audience & Prerequisites

  • ABAP developers who are new to RAP
  • Basic knowledge of CDS Views and ABAP Development Tools (ADT)
  • System used: SAP S/4HANA (On-Premise / Private Cloud)
  • Exposure type: OData V4
  • Scenario covered: Basic Read-only RAP application

    Mandatory Objects in a RAP Application:

    • Package
    • Interface CDS View
    • Projection CDS View (Optional we can directly create service definition on Interface view also)
    • Service Definition
    • Service Binding
  1. Create Package: 

    Create a package in ADT:

    • Right-click on project â†’ New â†’ ABAP Package
    • Enter package name and description
    • Do not create it as a local package ($TMP)
    • Capture it in a transport request     
    • Only transportable packages can be moved to Quality and Production systems.

    •  

  2. Interface CDS View: A CDS View is a virtual data model in ABAP that defines how data from database tables is accessed and represented. In RAP, it often serves as the â€œInterface View.â€

    1. Why It Matters:

      • Reusable logic: Centralizes data access for transactional and analytical purposes.
      • Foundation: Serves as the starting point for business object modeling in RAP.

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click your database table (e.g., ZTRAVEL_RAJ_M), select New Data Definition.
      • Provide a name, description, and use the Define View Entity template.
      • Assign to transport, activate, and check for errors.

      •  

  3. Service Definition: The Service Definition specifies which data elements (entities) of a RAP business object are exposed as OData services.

    1. Why It Matters:

      • Exposure Layer: Decides what consumers (e.g., Fiori apps, external APIs) can interact with.
      • Itâ€™s the contract between your backend logic and external consumers.
                                                                                                         

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click on the projection view, select New Service Definition.
      • Name, description, assign transport, and activate.
      • This exposes your RAP objects as a service.

      •  

  4. Service Binding: Service Binding links a service definition to an actual communication protocol (such as OData V4) and activation state.
    1. Why It Matters:
      • Enables Consumption: Without binding, your service cannot be called or used.
      • Protocol Choice: Determines how front ends communicate with your service (e.g., OData V4 for Fiori/UI5 apps).

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click on the service definition, select New Service Binding.
      • Choose OData V4 protocol (for most Fiori/RAP apps).
      • Assign transport, describe, finish, and activate.

      •  

      •  

  5. Why You Should NOT Publish from ADT: Publishing directly from ADT is meant only for local testing.

    1. Issues with ADT Publishing

      • Service is registered as a local ($TMP) object
      • Cannot be transported to Quality or Production
      • Not supported for productive landscapes

    2. Correct Way: Publish via /IWFND/V4_ADMIN

      • Transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN is the recommended way to publish RAP services.

    3. Steps: 
      • Open /IWFND/V4_ADMIN and click Publish Service Groups

      •  

      • Enter System Alias = LOCAL, Service Binding name click on get service groups

      •  

      • Select service and Publish

      •  

      • From the service group list, right click on your service group and click on transport publishing. It will prompt for customizing TR enter the transport and save. After that Click on transport routing assignment and capture in the customizing TR.

      •  

      •  

      • Service is now published

      •  

  6. Preview: Finally, letâ€™s preview the application to verify that the service is working as expected. 

    •  

Conclusion: 

  • In this blog, we learned how to create a basic RAP application and the correct approach to publish and transport OData V4 services to the Quality system.
  • Using /IWFND/V4_ADMIN ensures transport safety and helps avoid common deployment issues that beginners often face.

Note: 

To customize the user interface of your RAP application, add appropriate UI annotations in the CDS view (interface or projection, depending on your design). Common annotations include @ui.headerInfo, @ui.lineItem, and @ui.selectionField.

After publishing the service, share the service URL (available in the Service Binding) with the Fiori development team so they can create the required Fiori tile.
After transporting to the Quality system, SICF activation is a manual step. Without activating the relevant SICF nodes, the service will not be accessible. Coordinate with your Basis team to complete this step.

entry.title: SAP UX Q1/2026 Update â€“ Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, SAP SuccessFactors etc., as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, weâ€™ll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start. Highlights are the general availability of Joule Agent Builder as well as Document AI for SAP Mobile Start, and the two brand new innovations in beta and early adopter care respectively: Joule Deep Research and Joule Action Bar, taking user experience to the next level.

Here are the links to the other posts in the series published so far:

  • Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Before we get started: if you havenâ€™t already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q3/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update â€“ Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q3 2025.
  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q4/2025.
  • SAP Innovation Guide H2/2025 â€“ SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, weâ€™ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities with the generally available Agent Builder.

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Small Talk Pattern â€“ beyond just small talk.
  • Use Joule now in 13 languages (2 more added).
  • Joule, Deep research capability (Beta).
  • Joule Action Bar (EAC).
  • Joule on Mobile Devices â€“ now for SAP Sales Cloud too.
  • Joule Analytics Center For Analysing Usage.
  • Joule for Consultants: UX enhancement (Prompt Guide and Library).
  • Product-specific capabilities.
  • Customer-specific Agents: Agent Builder Available Now.

Joule Small Talk Pattern â€“ Beyond just Small Talk

Initially, you could say hello to Joule, and Joule would reply in a friendly way â€“ in other words, Joule could do small talk. In the mean time, we have significantly expanded the degree to which Joule supports general conversations.

Figure 1 shows an example, where the user has asked Joule the following:

Iâ€™m an HR manager preparing a script for a new hire onboarding presentation. The focus is on our companyâ€™s commitment to employee development, mentorship, and overall well-being. Please help me draft clear and engaging talking points that highlight why mentorship and professional growth are core values in our organization. Use the mission statement â€œhelp the world to run better.

To which Joule responds with a structured answer, with sections containing bullet points with suggestions.


Figure 1: An example of Joule small talk pattern, going beyond just small talk, shown with Joule in full-screen mode. Alt Text: Screenshot of Joule with the example query shown at the top, and below that Jouleâ€™s answer with sections â€œIntroductionâ€, â€œCommitment to Employee Developmentâ€ and â€œMentorship as a Core Valueâ€ visible.

Figure 2 gives an overview of all the five interaction patterns supported by Joule today â€“ the four patterns which interact with an SAP system, plus the small talk pattern.


Figure 2: The five Joule interaction patterns. Alt Text: Five images of Joule showing from left to right the Informational pattern (â€œWhat?â€), Navigational (â€œWhere?â€), Transactional (â€œDoâ€), Analytical (â€œShow meâ€) and Small Talk (â€œBe creativeâ€).

Use Joule in 13 Languages â€“ Two More Added

Since my last update, we have added support for Arabic and Indonesian, bringing the total up to 13. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Arabic
  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Indonesian
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portuguese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

In addition to these, we have four more languages available as a preview that are not yet officially supported:

  • Czech
  • Dutch (Netherlands)
  • Italian
  • Turkish

To get the most up-to-date information about language support for Joule, look at the documentation:

  • Joule Multi Language Support.

Joule, Deep Research Capability (Beta)

Currently available for beta-testing, the deep research capability means that Joule can provide much deeper insights in response to queries, by using external web resources in addition to those from your organization and SAP data.

One of our AI UX principles is â€œhuman in controlâ€, and hence we let users choose when they want a deep research analysis instead of the standard analysis (Figure X). Similarly, the deep research is done in two stages, where first the system shows the user the steps it plans to take in order to do the research, and asks the user to confirm before continuing (as shown in Figure Y).

Figures 3 â€“ 7 give you an idea of what it currently looks like, starting with the user selecting the deep research option, as shown in Figure 2. Joule then displays the research approval request, summarizing the steps it plans to take (Figure 4). Once the user has approved this, the research is done and the outcome shown. Finally, the user can expand the Sources section to get links to articles on which the research was based. In this case, the sources were all external.


Figure 3: Users can choose the answer type â€œDeep Researchâ€ (currently Beta) and then enter their question. Alt Text: Two images showing the text entry field for Joule, the upper one showing the context menu with the options for Answer Types â€œDefaultâ€ and â€œDeep Researchâ€, the lower one showing a â€œDeep Researchâ€ token displayed in the field, with a query entered â€œWhat is the name and weight of the eBike MZ-FG-E164, compare it to the average weight of similar bikes found online for the top 3 market sellers in only Germany region in the past 6 monthsâ€.


Figure 4: Joule deep research (beta) provides research approval request to the user. Alt Text: Image showing the Joule providing a formatted text with â€œResearch Approval Requestâ€ in large bold font as the title, with sections â€œResearch Planâ€ and â€œScopeâ€, each with bullet points outlining what Joule plans to do, such as â€œLook up the eBike model in internal systemsâ€¦â€, â€œResearch online sources..â€.


Figure 5: The outcome of the deep research â€“ first page. Alt Text: Image showing that the user prompted â€œStart Deep Researchâ€, followed by the beginning of the outcome text: the title in bold (â€œComparison of â€¦ to Top German eBike Sellersâ€™ Modelsâ€), with sections â€œOverviewâ€ and â€œKey Findingsâ€.


Figure 6: The outcome of the deep research â€“ second page. Alt Text: Image showing the section â€œAnalysisâ€ with sub-sections â€œWeight Comparison by Categoryâ€ and â€œComparative Analysisâ€, followed by the beginning of the section â€œConclusionâ€.


Figure 7: The outcome of the deep research, with links to sources. Alt Text: Image showing the remainder of the Conclusion, with a sub-section â€œData Access Noticeâ€, followed by a list of five sources with their titles and links to each of them.

To get an even better idea of how it works, watch it in action, or read more:

  • Video: Joule Deep Research example (2:06 minutes)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Joule, Deep research capability

Joule Action Bar (EAC)

The Joule Action Bar is an intelligent overlay in the browser that delivers AI on any application â€“ SAP and beyond.

It is available to early adopters as part of our early adopter care (EAC) program, allowing us to gather feedback from participating customers and iterate further before releasing it to everyone.

The Joule Action Bar hovers over your browser content and understands what users are currently doing. Powered by WalkMeâ€™s unique technology that interprets screen-based content, it can proactively step in to provide guidance, as well as being called up by the user on-demand. A particularly powerful feature is personalization: users can personalize the experience by creating custom AI actions for everyday tasks, not only for SAP systems, also for others.

Figures 8 and 9 show an example where the action bar is being used to deal with a support ticket in ServiceNow that indicates that urgent action is required. Normally, the user would have to switch to a separate SAP screen and analyze the issue, but the Joule Action Bar provides a summary of the pertinant information such at your fingertips â€“ in this case the impact summary.


Figure 8: Joule action bar visible while processing a ticket in ServiceNow. Alt Text: A screenshot with the Joule action bar visible at the bottom of the screen, on top of a greyed-out ServiceNow ticket screen. The action bar offers icons to open Joule, and buttons â€œSuggestionsâ€, â€œView supply chaing impactâ€, â€œToolsâ€ and personalization.


Figure 9: Joule action bar providing a summary of the supply chain impact. Alt Text: Image showing a pop-over â€œView supply chain impactâ€ above the Joule action bar, summarizing the impact, explaining stock availability and providing a risk alert.

Itâ€™s main benefits are:

  • Always available in a userâ€™s flow of work.
  • Detecting user needs in real time and offering help without being asked.
  • Proactively recommends next best actions based on screen-based and business context.
  • One consistent, unified and intuitive AI experience across SAP and non-SAP applications.
  • Personalization: allows users to create custom AI actions for their typical activities.

To get an even better idea of how it works, watch this short video:

  • Video: Joule Action Bar (1:15 minutes)
  • SAP Discovery Center: WalkMe, SAP Joule action bar (Proactive).
  • SAP Discovery Center: WalkMe, SAP Joule action bar (On-Demand).

Joule on Mobile Devices â€“ now for SAP Sales Cloud too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP Sales Cloud mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like updating status, expected value, sales phase of opportunities, and more, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can open a sales deal.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.
